fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a user tries to change the email of an Atlassian account at https://id.atlassian.com/ to an email that already has an Atlassian account, a message is sent to the new email, informing that the change is not possible because the email already has an Atlassian account. 
However, users are receiving an incomplete message, not informing the reason why the change is not possible.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Log in https://id.atlassian.com using an email that has an Atlassian account;
# Try to change the email at https://id.atlassian.com/manage/change-email to another email that already has an Atlassian account;

h3. Expected Results

An email should be sent to the new email, informing that the change is not possible because that email already has an Atlassian account. The message used to be like this:

"Your email change request could not be processed because (email_address) is already associated with another Atlassian account."

h3. Actual Results

The user receives an incomplete message:

 !couldn't change email.png|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround

No workarounds.
fields.summary: Incomplete email change request message

fields.description:
Currently, if the user uses an email address that doesn't have a valid user in Atlassian's products, the user faces an error message that is not clear.
 
Steps to reproduce
# Go to log in page
# Use *Log in with Google* button
# Choose an email that doesn't have a valid account on Atlassian's end
# The error message is the following  
!Screen Shot 2018-09-04 at 14.48.42.png|thumbnail! 

This error message should be more clear and inform that no user has been found in Altassian's system with that email address.
fields.summary: Provide a more detailed error message for authentication problem using G Suite

fields.description:
h3. Scenario

Currently, if the customer loses their _recovery key_ or it stops working, the account recover method placed [on our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/secure-your-account-with-two-step-verification-939505063.html#Secureyouraccountwithtwo-stepverification-troubleTroubleshoottwo-stepverification] (at *If your recovery key doesn't work or you've lost it* section) take at least 48 hours so the customer can log in again. That might cause customer frustration and can be a roadblock for his work.
h3. Suggestion

Reduce that delay time to send the email with the recovery link.
h3. Workaround 

If you are able to change your domain's DNS records and the Atlassian Account you have is related to that domain you can:
 # Create an [Organization|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/organization-administration-938859734.html].
 # [Verify your domain|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/domain-verification-873871234.html] (the DNS method is recommended). 
- If your account is already managed by an Org, please contact your Org administrator to have the *2FA* disabled for your account.

With that you will have access to all accounts under your domain and will be able to disable the _*two-step verification*_ manually at the *Organization* > *Managed accounts* > search for the user you want to disable _2FA_ > select _disable 2FA_ at the drop-down menu.
fields.summary: Reduce the time the customer needs to wait to recover the account when lost 2FA recovery key

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As per [Important notice: Upcoming changes to Jira Cloud REST APIs to improve user privacy|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/api-changes-for-user-privacy-announcement//] in the future the key and name attributes will be removed from the user object returned in REST API calls.

With that in mind, REST API consumers will only be able to identify users through the {{accountId}}, {{emailAddress}}(which can be null depending on user privacy) and {{displayName}} attributes.

In case the user privacy is set so the *emailAddress* is not returned and the user has changed his display name to something unrelated to him how can site-admins determine what user they are dealing with just by the accountId?

h3. Suggested Solution

If compliant to the GDPR law implement an access level on the REST API calls which will recognize the user making the calls as a site-admin and thus return the user email or full name history for better identification.

h3. Current state

The privacy changes have been [rolled out|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/blog/2019/05/upcoming-changes-to-atlassian-account-profiles] and at the current state, site-admins can only see the email information from all users regardless of their privacy settings through the UI.

This means that through the user-related rest endpoints site-admins won't be able to see the email address of users depending on their privacy settings.
If the email address fetched from Atlassian is being used by any integrations please refer to the below documentation to get your integration migrated into a connect app or to use 3LO and thus get access to the specific endpoint to get user email addresses:
* [Guidelines for requesting access to email address \- Announcements \- The Atlassian Developer Community|https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/guidelines-for-requesting-access-to-email-address/27603]
* [Integrating with Jira Cloud|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/integrating-with-jira-cloud/]
fields.summary: Implement access level to user object returned in rest API calls

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When you deactivate a user that has the "Permission" field set to "Basic", after clicking the Deactivate button the permission will change to "Trusted" mistakenly, as well as messing with the style of the field.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user or access an existing one
# Make sure its Permission is set to Basic
# Click the Deactivate button

h3. Expected Results
The user is deactivated and no other change is made
h3. Actual Results
The Permission changes to "Trusted" and the style of the field changes
 
h3. Notes
Tested on Chrome Beta and Firefox Developer Edition.

h3.Workaround
Refreshing the page should return the user to "Basic" permission and fix the field style.
fields.summary: Deactivating/Activating a user will mistakenly mark "Basic" user as "Trusted"

No workaround

The People Directory has gone through an update, and alongside this update, users who are part of a verified domain, are no longer able to search users from the same Company, that has a different verified domain.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Usernames are still visible in the URL of the users profile


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to User Management
# Hover your mouse over or click on a user and notice the username is displayed in the URL

h3. Expected Results

The banner mentions we are phasing out usernames, so the customer does not expect to see the username in the URL

h3. Actual Results
The username is included in the URL e.g.
https://<jira>.atlassian.net/admin/users/view?username=user.name1
 
h3. Notes
I have advised the customer we are still in the process of removing usernames from our backend and that it may take a few months to complete. But having a bug report will make it trackable.

h3.Workaround
No known workaround.
fields.summary: Usernames are still visible in the URL of the users profile

fields.description:
Currently Atlassian Access and Atlassian G Suite integration fight for domain claims. I.e an administrator can claim example.com in Atlassian Access, configure Atlassian G Suite integration on a site-level for example.com and lose the claim in Atlassian Access.

Whilst this limitation is partially documented on the [Atlassian Access documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/domain-verification-873871234.html]:

{quote}
Your users authenticate with Google. Because you verify your domain as part of your integration with Google, you can't verify your domain from your Atlassian Cloud site. If you want to verify your domain, you'll need to disconnect the G Suite integration.
{quote}

This is still highly confusing to customers since they can only manage Atlassian Accounts with the Atlassian Access claim, and the distinction between managed users and users on site is not often well understood.

One scenario is that an administrator blocks a user in Atlassian Access, configures the G Suite integration and hence can not unblock the user anymore. The error message indicates that a user should contact their organization administrator who is then left confused because he will assume that this is a site-level restriction. Whilst this can be easily remedied by an administrator by clicking the re-verify button Atlassian Access, he is going to lose this claim again on the next scheduled G Suite run.
fields.summary: Atlassian Access and Atlassian G Suite integration should share domain claims

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of 31 Jan 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#4C9AFF|bgColor=#DEEBFF}
Hi everyone,

Today we released documentation for new APIs that allow organization administrators to edit accounts that are [managed by their organization|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/set-up-an-atlassian-organization-938859734.html]. Once you have created an organization and [verified your domain|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/verify-a-domain-for-your-organization-873871234.html], you can use the following APIs to manage accounts:
 * [The Organizations API|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/admin/organization/rest/] is available to list all the managed accounts in your organization. You can use this to enumerate the unique _Atlassian account ID_ for each users.
 * [The User management API|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/admin/user-management/rest/] is available to edit individual users. 
** You can use this API to edit attributes for a given Atlassian account ID using the {{PATCH /users/ \{account_id\}/manage/profile}} method.
** You can use the {{POST /users/\{account_id\}/manage/lifecycle/disable}} and {{enable}} methods to disable or enable accounts in bulk.

The types of changes you can make with this API include:
 * Enabling/disabling the Atlassian account
 * Changing user email addresses or departments

For other bulk user management changes, we recommend using the User provisioning (SCIM) API to sync users and groups from an external system. [The documentation for the SCIM API|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/admin/user-provisioning/rest/] is also now available.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
Atlassian Access Product Management
{panel}

h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, there's no public documented API on Atlassian Access

h3. Suggested Solution
A REST API allowing org admin to easily manage a huge amount of users.

Providing a supported API provides the ability for the org admin to perform the atlassian access feature in a bulk.

An example would be if there are a lot of managed accounts in the organization, to disable a certain number of accounts would take a lot of time OR if there are a lot of accounts that need to be updated, for example when there's a domain changed, to update the email address for all account would take a huge amount of time. 

With REST API, this task would be much easier to manage and with less time to spend.
fields.summary: Atlassian Access REST API

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce 
 # Setup SSO using Atlassian Access. 
 # Ask one of the managed users to log-out of Jira/Confluence Cloud 

 

Expected Behavior - User is logged out of Jira/Confluence Cloud and the SSO. 

Actual Behavior - User is only logged out of Jira/Confluence Cloud and the SSO session remains logged in. 

Suggestion - Please can you extend this functionality to terminate the user's SSO session once they log out of Jira/Confluence Cloud. 

 

Current Workaround - Educate the Jira/Confluence users to also logout of SSO once they sign out of Jira/Confluence Cloud.

fields.description:
*Summary*
Site access setting reverts to "Anyone can join"

*Environment*

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Choose the setting "Anyone with one of the following email address domains can join:", and type in a domain such as "google.com".
# Save settings.
# Refresh the page or navigate away and back.
# Observe that the setting now reads "Anyone can join".

*Expected Results*
The domain is added under the field "Anyone with one of the following email address domains can join:"

*Actual Results*
Observe that the setting now reads "Anyone can join" and anyone can create a new account with a non-google.com domain, such as gmail.com.

*Workaround*
Type the domain and click on tab after that. Then, make sure that the domain is added under the field. "Anyone with one of the following email address domains can join:"
fields.summary: Site access setting reverts to "Anyone can join"

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently there is no way for admins to check how often their users are logging in

h3. Suggested Solution

Have a page which tracks logins for users

h3. Why this is important

Admins may need to prune accounts that are not used often and having this information will help them decide which accounts need to be removed

h3. Workaround 

View the 'Last active' date on the User Management page to see when the user last logged in
fields.summary: As an admin I want to be able to view login counts for user accounts

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, changing the profile picture on behalf of a user can't be done by the administrator. Only the account owners can change their very own profile picture. Administrators of managed accounts don't have a direct access to personal content that the user create or update on their profile. For example, an administrator won't be able to change/upload the profile picture posing as the user.

h3. Why this is important
In a situation where you have inactive users but would still like to keep the data but not the profile picture, the admin would require to change the profile picture on behalf of the user. Or in a case where a standard of profile picture must be met, a full control/access to profile picture would be really helpful.

h3. Workaround 
In the managed account, change the email address to any email address that you'll be able to access, verify it and access https://id.atlassian.com using the updated email address. Upload a new profile picture and go back to the managed account page to revert back the email address.
fields.summary: As an org admin, I would like to upload a profile picture on behalf of a managed acount

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Using correct email address and API Token (or password) is not working when authenticating REST API calls. 

h3. Notes
The bug in on the Identity side, and it will equally affect Jira, Confluence and Stride. This usually happens when using managed accounts (using SSO or Google Sync to log-in) and it is caused by some change that didn't propagate correctly, like, e.g:
# A user change's their email
# SAML user changes email at the IdP
# User has their email updated by an org admin

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Log into the instance and open an issue (e.g. ISSUE-123)
# From the browser, call the REST endpoint to get the issue information and see that you get the correct response (https://INSTANCE/rest/api/latest/issue/ISSUE-123)
# Generate an API Token and use it to authenticate a REST API call against the same endpoint (https://INSTANCE/rest/api/latest/issue/ISSUE-123)

h3. Expected Results
You get the same REST response than in step 2

h3. Actual Results
You get error {color:#DE350B}401 Unauthorized{color} instead.


h3.Workaround
 It is usually enough to log into id.atlassian.com with email address and password (better if from an incognito/anonymous window) to have the changes propagated.
fields.summary: Cannot authenticate REST API calls using right credentials (API Token). Getting 401 Unauthorized

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If we synchronize a specific user from Google Suite to an Atlassian Cloud site, the Google ID of this user is registered and so this user cannot be deleted. If the synchronization is removed and another is added (without that user), the Google ID remains and we cannot delete the user, as the option is greyed out.

This will only happen is another G Suite account is added.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a G Suite Account and a user, add it to a group
# Synchronize this group to an Atlassian site
# Stop the synchronization
# Remove the user from the group
# Re-add the G Suite account, synchronizing the same group (this time without that user)

h3. Expected Results
You can delete the user as it's not part of the current association with G Suite.

h3. Actual Results
The user cannot be deleted because it contains a Google ID and since a G Suite account is linked, it incorrectly considers the user as a synced user and the delete button is greyed out:
!greyed_out.png|thumbnail!

h3.Workaround
The user can be deleted by bypassing the button. Use this link to go to a delete page and confirm:
{code}
https://instance.atlassian.net/admin/users/delete?username=<username>
{code}
fields.summary: Cannot delete user previous synchronized with Google Suite

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Consider this scenario:
* A user have 2 Atlassian Accounts under different domains:
** ezra@atlassian.com
** ezra@myowncompany.com
* The user is accessing multiple Jira/Confluence Cloud sites:
** ezra@atlassian.com for https://atlassian.atlassian.net
** ezra@myowncompany.com for https://myowncompany.atlassian.net
* The user would like to use ezra@atlassian.com to access from now onwards
* It is not possible to make the change, and a workaround from Cloud support team is required

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow mapping of a Jira/Confluence account to an Atlassian Account through the site-admin UI

h3. Why this is important
It is common for users to have multiple email addresses, and it is not easy to map these email addresses to a Jira/Confluence account with the current Cloud setup. 

h3. Workaround 
Contact Atlassian Cloud support team
fields.summary: As a site-admin, I would like to change the email address used by a Jira/Confluence account

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Users cannot log in to Atlassian Cloud using Mozilla Firefox web browser if First-Party Isolation (FPI) is enabled (privacy.firstparty.isolate=true). FPI is an optional privacy feature built-in to Firefox that enforces stricter security policies to block tracking between websites.
h3. Suggested Solution

The log in for Atlassian Cloud should be run solely in Atlassian Cloud as FPI option does not allow authentication from other URLs other than the one where the user is trying to log in to.
h3. Workaround

No workaround, Currently First-Party Isolation (FPI) must be disabled (privacy.firstparty.isolate=false)in the Firefox Settings
fields.summary: Allow users to login with First-Party Isolation (FPI) enabled in Firefox

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, we have to deactivate user one by one, and there is no way to bulk deactivate them

h3. Suggested Solution
Allows "selecting" or "marking" multiple users that we would like to deactivate

h3. Why this is important

h3. Workaround 
None at the moment
fields.summary: Allows selecting or marking multiple users to deactivate them

fields.description:
From a Support case:
Security wise the present logon procedure is bad because the same password is used for different Confluence sites. This is against all rules of information security!
On top of this: when I log off for one site, I automatically am logged off at all the sites I have access to.
Again: please reconsider this procedure. Best is: each site (URL) a different logon/password.
fields.summary: Current functionality of Atlassian Account is deemed unsecure

fields.description:
h3. *Summary*

The customer is concerned with the level of permission a user (account connected to the G Suite) needs to be able to synchronise with G Suite.

According to him, such levels of permission "opens an attack vector".

h3. Suggestion

Remove the need to check the *Domain settings* or the *Domain management* permission
in the G Suite for the connected user.
fields.summary: Remove the need of checking the *Domain settings* permission when synchronising with G Suite

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Accounts created by G Suite sync cannot be deleted *even after the user has been removed from a synced group*.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect your instance with G Suite and sync a group with a user
# Remove the user from that group in G Suite OR remove that group from the list of groups to sync
# Try to delete that user

h3. Expected Results
The user can be deleted

h3. Actual Results
It's not possible to delete the user. The option to delete them is greyed out:
!delete-greyed-out.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workarounds
* Deactivate the user instead of deleting it, or
* Disconnect G Suite, delete the user, then reconnect, or
* Readd the user to a synced group, perform a sync, then remove the user from the synced group.
fields.summary: Cannot delete user created by G Suite sync even after removal from synced group

fields.description:
{panel:title= Resolved|bgColor=#e2f7fc}
We have identified and addressed the issue that was delaying user management synchronization in JIRA Cloud and Confluence Cloud; this issue has been resolved.
{panel}

h3. Summary
New Users who have been invited/added to an Atlassian Cloud Instance are unable to login after verifying their accounts.  These users are presented with a message:

{quote}Your operation is taking longer than usual
Sorry, your operation is taking longer than usual. Please try again in a few minutes.

If you're still seeing this screen after ten minutes please raise a support request.{quote}

!Login.png|thumbnail!

New Groups and Group Membership Changes performed within User Management are not currently seen in Jira/Confluence


*Updates available on StatusPage*: https://status.atlassian.com/incidents/7cp3c7jk2fvx

h3. Environment
* Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# As a Site-Admin, create a New User who has Application Access in the Instance
# New User receives the invitation and completes the Signup/Registration process


h3. Expected Results
New User is able to login

h3. Actual Results
See error above
 
h3. Notes
Existing Users are able to login without issues

h3.Workaround
none
fields.summary: Newly Created Users Are Unable to Login

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The Google ID of a user is associated with the incorrect Atlassian ID(AID).  Customers may have multiple AIDs because of an email address change(or similar).  Login process fails as described in "Actual Results" below.  Users are unintentionally forced to authenticate with the incorrect AID as a result of the Google ID being associated with the incorrect AID.

h3. Environment
* JIRA 1000.910.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Google Apps(G-Suite) for single sign-on
# Try to log into instance using the correct email address and password

h3. Expected Results
* Successful login and access to JIRA/Confluence, OR
* Error message stating that PrimaryEmail@example.com doesn't have access

h3. Actual Results
* User is presented with an error that reads similar to:
{quote}
Aw, shoot. You don't have access with
NotPrimaryEmail@example.com

Looks like you don't have access to this site.
{quote}
* The email address displayed in the error message is not the primary email of the Google account that the customer used to log in.
 
h3. Notes
* All users on an instance are denied access to JIRA in some cases
fields.summary: G-Suite associated with incorrect Atlassian ID

fields.description: Some customers are requesting the ability for site-admins to close no longer used Atlassian Accounts.
fields.summary: The ability for site-admins to close unused Atlassian Accounts

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The feature that allows you to login as another user in the User Management is not working in the Atlassian Home feature.

h3. Environment
* Jira Cloud User Management
* Atlassian Home

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# create a test user with access to no projects
# with your main admin user, go to the newly created user profile in the UM
# click Login as user
# in Jira everything should look fine, as you will see Jira as this user
# access the Atlassian Home by clicking the hamburger (app switch) menu

h3. Expected Results
As the newly created user has no access in Jira projects and issues, he should not see anything

h3. Actual Results
You will see all your recent visited projects (from the main admin account) as well as other users in the People section, information that you should not see as you're impersonating the new user.

h3. Notes
It appears that the home section is not respecting the active user logged in by the tool *login as user* and is using the admin profile to navigate.

h3. Workaround
fields.summary: Atlassian Home not working with Login as user feature

fields.description:
The customers are requesting the ability to set up a notification to be fired when a user is created or deleted.

All the administrators should be notified when a user is modified.
fields.summary: Generate a notification when user is created or deleted

fields.description:
With an active session in the same browser, it is not possible to log on to both sites as you have to log off or close the browser or delete the cookies or restart the browser (a mess, if you have active connections to other sites and a bunch of tabs are open).

 

Having the possibility to login with multiple accounts in the same browser will offer the users more comfort. E.g. In GSuite, I can easily change the used Google-Account. 

 

Can you please consider this feature for a future release?
fields.summary: Log in with multiple accounts in the same browser

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, when verifying a domain under your Organization the verification process doesn't check if this domain hasn't been verified by another Organization already which results in the domain being verified in the current Org while leaving it superseded in the other. 

As all site-admins can create an Org this can likely generate confusion within companies.

h3. Suggested Solution

Implement a constraint that checks if the domain is already verified and in case it is, prompts to the user a warning message and does not complete the action.
fields.summary: Check if a domain is already verified by an Organization when verifying it.

fields.description: If I enter my email address then hit next I get taken to Google, but need to manually re-enter my email address. If Aa passed it to Google as the login_hint this double-entry screen would be skipped entirely.
fields.summary: Pass email address to Google for login

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Non-ASCII character in SAML attribute causes login failure.
h3. Environment
 * This unavailability is verified with OneLogin.
 * This didn't happen to the former SAML integration which is deprecated since [April 6th, 2018|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/saml-single-sign-on-943953302.html#SAMLsinglesign-on-UpdateyourSAMLconfiguration].

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Use multi-byte character in SAML attribute. For instance:
 ** givenname: チャーリー
 ** surname: アトラシアン
 # Set up SAML setting

h3. Expected Results

Non-ASCII character in SAML attribute causes login failure.
h3. Actual Results

Login fails with the error "Oops, there was an error logging you in".

In HAR file, you can see the error message starting with:
{code:none}
Signature check errors: invalid signature: ...
{code}
h3. Workaround
 * Do not use any non-ASCII character in SAML attributes
fields.summary: OneLogin doesn't support non-ASCII characters with the newer SAML integration

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* In some organizations, the list of "Managed accounts" is not accessible
* Organization admins are seeing "Something went wrong. Please try again later"

h3. Environment
* Domain(s) verified
* Organization created

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open User Management
# Navigate to your organization directly or to https://admin.atlassian.com/
# Select "Managed accounts"

h3. Expected Results
* A list of managed users is fetched

h3. Actual Results
 !Screen Shot 2018-05-07 at 2.19.12 PM.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Notes
* The issue seems to occur in organizations where there are multiple verified domains

h3.Workaround
* Use a domain filter: [instance_name].atlassian.net/admin/o/[organization_id]/members?domain=[domain_name] e.g. https://example_only.atlassian.net/admin/o/aaaa-bbbb-cccc-dddd-eeee/members?domain=example_domain.example
fields.summary: Unable to access list of managed accounts

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Currently, in [SAML single sign-on|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/saml-single-sign-on-943953302.html] documentation is not updated with how to setup JIRA Service Desk customer account login with SSO.

h3. Environment
Cloud


h3. Expected Results
Update the documentation with the context below :-
{panel}
*How to set up JIRA Service Desk customer account login with SSO*
# For existing customer account , search the user in *Portal Only Customer* list by go to *User Management > JIRA Service Desk > Portal only Customer*
# Open the user profile and click *Migrate to Atlassian Account*
# Then , it will redirect to user profile with that have the application access/group information. Make sure to remove all the application access because Customer account don't require an application access and it will not counted in any license. 
# Now , open the Customer Portal and key in the email. If the email already in the Organization managed account , it will be redirected to SSO.
{panel}

h3. Actual Results
No information about JIRA Service Desk customer account.
fields.summary: SAML SSO documentation is not updated about how to set up JIRA Service Desk Customer using SSO

fields.description:
h3. Summary
"Jira Service Desk" option intermittently missing from the Sidebar

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to Site Administration

h3. Expected Results
If JIRA Service Desk is installed on the instance, there should be 4 options available under "User Management":
* Users
* Groups
* Application Access
* JIRA Service Desk

h3. Actual Results
Only 3 options show on the sidebar:
* Users
* Groups
* Application Access

h3. Notes
* This happens intermittently

h3.Workaround
* Refresh the page
fields.summary: "Jira Service Desk" option Sometimes Missing from Sidebar

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Jira Cloud cannot be used with Microsoft Intune enrolled devices on Conditional Access and Azure AD Single Sign On because the login process uses a "browser" that is not accepted by Intune. This happens exclusively with Conditional Access into Microsoft Intune that allows managed browsers only (Safari and the Intune Managed browser).

h3. Environment
Mobile

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Subscribe to Microsoft Intune (app management controls)
# Log in Jira cloud instance via Jira App

h3. Expected Results

- Successful Log in and accessibility to Jira

h3. Actual Results
- The login redirected to the Microsoft Login for the authentication and since your “browser” is not Safari or the Intune Managed Browser, we cannot login into the application.
fields.summary: Jira Cloud mobile not working on Microsoft Intune managed devices

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In the User management part of the Cloud applications, under the *Application Access* menu, the user has an option to Grant Access and select the "All Active Users" option. When clicking on this option, a message that "System users product access cannot be removed" will be displayed:

 

!admin.png|thumbnail!

 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # As a member of the *site-admins* group, go to the *User management* of the application (Application Navigator > User Management)
 # Click on *Application Access*
 # Click on the *Grant Access* button
 # Select *All Active Users* and click on *Grant Access* again.

 

h3. Expected Results

The user should be able to grant access to the members of the application.

h3. Actual Results
A message blocking the operation will be displayed.
h3. Notes
As non-system-administrator users do not have permissions to remove/grant access to system users (like add-on users, for example), when selecting the option to grant it to all active users, it will also select the system users.

h3.Workaround
Contact the Atlassian Support since members of the staff are system-administrator users.
fields.summary: Grant Access Button not Working for "All Active Users"

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Stride signup flow allows any users to request accesses to Confluence and Jira as default applications

h3. Environment
* Atlassian Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# User Management: Select "No account can self signup"
# Stride: Select "Join an existing team" > the Atlassian Cloud tenant
# Site-admin receives an approval request email
**  !um_approval_request.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
Site-admin receives approval requests only if it's allowed on User Management

h3. Actual Results
Site-admin won't receive any approval requests if it's prohibited on User Management

h3.Workaround
* None
fields.summary: Stride doesn't respect self signup configuration on User Management

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Users full name is not updated after a GSynch is run. His AAID full name does not reflect the full name that he changed at GSuite

h3. How to Replicate

# Setup an  instance with  Cloud , use GSuite for all users on  the domain say abc.com
# One of he user on abc.com is user1@abc.com
# User1 than changes his full name at GSuite
# Full name should reflect correctly at Atlassian UM or {{id.atlassian.com}}
# But it does not reflect the full name

Workaround if relevant, could be as below  :
 
Based on [GSuite FAQ|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/g-suite-faqs-873871245.html#GSuiteFAQs-WhyisthefullnameinmyAtlassianaccountnotsynchronizedwiththefullnamefrommyGoogleprofile?] : 
{quote}
Why is the full name in my Atlassian account not synchronized with the full name from my Google profile?
Google introduced a feature that allows G Suite administrators to give users the ability to edit their profile (see this Google documentation). However, the Atlassian integration with G Suite syncs with Google's Directory API and the data there, including a user's full name, can only be updated by G Suite administrators. Consequently, the name a user enters when they edit their Google profile differs from that available on the Directory API and is not available to the Atlassian G Suite integration.

We recommend not allowing user editing of their name (see this Google documentation) in order to avoid confusion.
{quote}

Customers want to be able to change their own Full Name and this Feature Request is to track efforts if any around this.
fields.summary: GSuite User Full Name cannot be updated

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If a user exists as a customer portal-only account, the same email can still be registered as an Atlassian user account
h3. Suggested Solution
Warn the admin of the existing customer portal-only account when the admin tries to create the Atlassian user account
h3. Why this is important
To avoid duplicate users
fields.summary: Warn admin if created user exist as a customer portal-only account

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a customer attempts to modify a system user (including to move an add-on user into a group) an error occurs.
{quote}System users product access cannot be removed{quote}
 !large.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Suggested Solution
This is misleading since the user is not trying to remove access, but just add them to a new group. The cause of this error is that customers are not able to modify system users in any way.

Perhaps we can modify the error message to tell them that they're not able to modify system users, not that you can't remove access.

h3. Why this is important
For clarity!

h3. Workaround
Generally it shouldn't be necessary to move an add-on user to a new group, but if it's required to work then you can contact Support to do so.
fields.summary: Attempting to move an add-on user into a new group causes misleading error

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Accounts created by G Suite sync cannot be deleted *even when G Suite has been disconnected*.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect your instance with G Suite and sync some users.
# *Disconnect the G Suite integration*
# Try to delete one of the users.

h3. Expected Results
The user is successfully deleted.

h3. Actual Results
It's not possible to delete any of the users. The option to delete them is greyed out:
!delete-greyed-out.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workarounds
* Deactivate the user instead of deleting it, or
* Disconnect G Suite, delete the user, then reconnect.
fields.summary: Cannot delete user created by G Suite sync even after disconnection

fields.description:
h3. Summary

A new user is allowed to be created with the same email even if there is already a Jira Service Desk customer using this email.

 

Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to the [https://domain.atlassian.net/admin/users/invite] for a new user creation.
 # Create a new user using the same email you verified that there is a Jira Service Desk customer already using. For verifying the Jira Service Desk customers emails: [https://domain.atlassian.net/admin/jira-service-desk/portal-only-customers]
 # The user is normally created.

 
h3. Expected Results

The new user would not be created since the email is already being used for another user(even this being a Jira Service Desk Customer). The application should not allow the new user creation and advise to migrate the already existing customer for an Atlassian Account and Jira licensed user
h3. Actual Results

The new user is being created normally and you can see two users in the database with the same email.

 
h3. Workaround

In the [https://domain.atlassian.net/admin/jira-service-desk/portal-only-customers] you can choose the user, access it and click on the "Migrate to Atlassian Account" button. It will associate the Jira Service Desk customer with the already created user with the same email.
fields.summary: New user is allowed to be created even if the email is already being used for a Jira Service Desk customer

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If your domain is a GSuite domain and this domain is synced with another instance where isn't syncing your user, when changing your Full Name in your Google Account, it will not change the Full Name in the Atlassian Account

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user A with the domain @a.com for example, and sync this domain to an instance A
# Use a group-based sync, making sure that the user A isn't in this group, hence, the user isn't being synced to the instance A
# The user A creates a new instance B which isn't syncing with GSuite.
# Changes the Full Name in the Google Account.

h3. Expected Results
Upon the login, the Atlassian Account should pull the correct Full Name of the user from his Google Account.

h3. Actual Results
The user's Full Name isn't updated still shows the old Full Name.

h3. Workaround
- Sync the user to the instance A where the domain is verified.
- Stop the sync in the instance A.
fields.summary: The Atlassian Account Full Name isn't updating when the Google Account Full Name changes

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When we invite a new user, self signup option is selected by default for the domain.

h3. Suggested Solution
The option should be disabled by default.

h3. Why this is important
* This is a security concern as
** Admin may not aware of the option on the invitation
** Break of security policy for some companies which should never enable the self signup

h3. Workaround 
* Manually deselect the option when inviting the users.
* You can always disable the option via *Site Administrations > Self signup*
fields.summary: Self Signup Shouldn't Be Enabled Upon Inviting New User

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, site-admins of a site are not able to see if the users in their instance have enabled 2FA or not. 

For users under our own domain, we can check it through Organization. However, I might have a mix of domain and 3rd party users logging in to my site, and I am not sure if they have deactivated 2FA or not.

h3. Suggested Solution
In the user management, give a label for the users if they have 2FA activated or not.

h3. Why this is important
In order for us to be GDPR compliant, we have to ensure that 2FA is activated for the users. 

"since you are able to purchase 2FA as an add-on, the absence of this functionality in our base Atlassian products does not necessarily result in a violation of GDPR" --- the problem with this is that I am not able to enforce 2FA for users that are not under my domain.
fields.summary: Allow site-admin of an instance to see if the users in the site has activated two-factor authentication

fields.description:
This is in reference to impact to customers who setup Organisation and as part of it do a domain claim. 

Referring to : 

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/organization-administration-938859734.html]

And the following statement : 
{quote}Once you have verified a domain, all Atlassian accounts using the email address with the verified domain become managed accounts. 
{quote}
Customers especially from large organisation can have a negative impact if they are not made aware of the fact that when a domain is claimed under an Organisation - all users who have the same email domain irregardless of whether they only exist in the instance where the domain claim is done or elsewhere in any Atlassian Cloud instance will now be a managed account and as such can be impacted by any of the features/benefits imposed by the new Organisation Administrator including 2FA , Password Policy , SAML Authentication. 

Suggestion : 

Have a clear 'Warning Icon' highlighting the impact that users who will now be considered as a managed account will not only include users at that instance but any Atlassian Cloud instance potentially and usually meaning an increase of managed accounts. Which in turn can have an impact on both billing and the business continuity of other users on the same domain but using other instances.
fields.summary: Organisation Domain Claim Documentation Unclear that all users on any Atlassian Cloud instance not just their own will be impacted by domain claim

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Right now, organization admin must deactivate a user from User Management to completely deactivate a user account on Cloud instances. They cannot just do it from their IDP admin panel.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great to be able to deactivate user account directly from the IDP admin panel and not have to repeat the action a 2nd time and deactivate the user from the Cloud instance.
fields.summary: Deactivate users from Okta/Azure/etc.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, groups are managed within Atlassian Cloud and there's no way to map your group from your AD group.

h3. Suggested Solution
AD Groups, such as Developers and Admins to be mapped over to Atlassian Groups. For example, people in the "Administrators" AD Group will automatically be added to the "administrators" Atlassian group.

h3. Why this is important
Ideally, we would want the admin to manage user in only one platform/application.
fields.summary: Allow mapping Active Directory Groups to Atlassian Cloud Groups

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, in Atlassian Cloud, the maximum licensed user count is 2000 users (Confluence, JIRA Core, JIRA Software).

h3. Suggested Solution
Allowing to have more than 2000 users in Atlassian Cloud. 

h3. Why this is important
For huge companies, they have more than 2000 employees and 2000 users is too little for them.

h3. Workaround 
Server or multiple cloud instances
fields.summary: Allow more than 2000 users in Atlassian Cloud

fields.description:
*Summary*
Strong password shows an error message: "Your password must have a minimum strength of strong"

*Environment*

*Steps to Reproduce*
# access id.atlassian.com
# enter your email and use the "Can't log in?" link to send a recovery link
# use the recovery link to try and reset your password
# try a password like "qweqweqweqweqweq", for example
# this is reported as "Strong"
# press continue

*Expected Results*
The password will change

*Actual Results*
Jira gives you the message error: "Your password must have a minimum strength of strong"

*Workaround*
Use at least 12 characters with 3 capital letters and 3 special characters.
fields.summary: Strong password shows error message: "Your password must have a minimum strength of strong"

fields.description:
[Organization Administration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/organization-administration-938859734.html] explains how organizations are managed in Identity Manager in detail. 
The section about adding additional org-admins from other sites is not very clear. 

Scenario
# Two sites (instance1.atlassian.net) and (instance2.atlassian.net)
# Two site-admins - site-admin1 and site-admin2 on (instance1.atlassian.net) and (instance2.atlassian.net) respectively
# site-admin1 claimed a domain foo.com and is also the org-admin. 
# site-admin2 wishes to be added as an org-admin for foo.com

Solution
# Create site-admin2 as a user in (instance1.atlassian.net) and add the user to site-admins group. 
# Once added, follow the steps from [Organization Administration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/organization-administration-938859734.html] to mark site-admin2 as an org-admin. 
# After site-admin2 is an org-admin for domain foo.com - remove site-admin2 from (instance1.atlassian.net)

Please can you update the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/organization-administration-938859734.html] to reflect the correct steps.
fields.summary: Documentation Update

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Some accounts maybe prevented from logging in id.atlassian.com, looking at the browser console, they would see a 500 error while being redirected.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

-

h3. Expected Results

User will be able to log in.

h3. Actual Results

User receives an error displayed in the UI (There was an internal server error) the 500 POST error is logged in the browser console pointing to https://id.atlassian.com/rest/saml/sso

h3. Notes

Screenshot of the error

 !Screen Shot 2018-04-04 at 5.09.19 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Some accounts might be unable to log in at id.atlassian.com

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
 * When migrating Jira to the cloud environment and having Bitbucket on the server environment the user management is not centralized. 
 Instead both products are Atlassians', the userbase is separate and no synchronization is set to ensure centralizing the user management.

h3. Suggested Solution
 * We suggest to implement some way of synchronizing jira cloud userbase with crowd.

h3. Why this is important
 * This make the administration better centralized thus easier.

h3. Workaround
 * Using Identity providers for cloud (through Identity manager) and server (through add-ons).
fields.summary: synchronizing jira cloud userbase with crowd

fields.description:
When I try to login onto my OnDemand instance with incorrect password and captcha is active I always get "You must enter a valid verification word to log in." message - I tried captcha many times, so I rather typed it correctly at least once ;). I would expect to see incorrect credentials error rather than that one.

h3. How to reproduce:
1. Go to https://ecosystem.atlassian.net
2. Logout
3. Try to login few times with incorrect password until captcha appear
4. Solve captcha and try to login with incorrect password
5. [BUG] You'll see following error message: "You must enter a valid verification word to log in." 

h3. Suggested Fix
The message should be changed to clarify that either the password or the verification word might be wrong.
fields.summary: Misleading login error message when captcha is active

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The Application access page has some sorting issues.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have an instance with several users, enough to fill more than one page of the application access.

h3. Expected Results
 - The list of users is sorted by username, taking all users into consideration.

h3. Actual Results
 - The list of users is sorted by username, however, this sorting is happening on each page individually.
For example, the page 1, is ordered by A > Z, and if you have enough users to fill another page, this page is also ordered by A > Z.:
- Page 1:
 !Page 1.png|thumbnail! 
- Page 2:
 !Page 2.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

None.
fields.summary: The Application access page has some sorting issues.

fields.description:
*Problem Description*

When a user is added to the instance, user gets redirected, indicating that the password is wrong, even though it's was just reseted.
It was reproduced on Chrome and Safari.

*Steps to Reproduce* (when affected):

Add an user and the user tries to confirm the account, it gets redirected.

*Expected behaviour:*
It should allow you to log in, without any trouble.

*Actual behaviour:*
Keeps showing an error of wrong password.

*Workaround*

Complete the signup on Firefox.
fields.summary: Can't Login or Reset Password

fields.description:
This has happened twice with me.

->ABC have account on abc.atlassian.net

->XYZ have account on xyz.atlassian.net

->Now in conference room ABC accessed abc.atlassian.com and w/o logged in closed the instance

->Later on the same browser XYZ accessed xyz.atlassian.net

Got error page with message

"You havent been to this site before

The site allows self signup so you can join using [xyz@xyz.com.|mailto:xyz@xyz.com.] You can also switch the account is you want to use the different email address

"

-> Later i click "Join with this account"

And my account gets created in abc.atlassian.net  and i am able to do activities

 

Issue:
 # Like wise anyone can access any other vendor Jira
 # Sometimes it gives you error but on refresh account is automatically getting created and perform the activites
fields.summary: User is able to access another JIRA

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Having 3rd party cookies disabled will have the Site administration menu displays its old menus such as *Authentication*. The new menus are not visible as well as other older menus such as *Application access*.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Disable 3rd party cookies in your browser
# Visit the *User management* page.

h3. Expected Results
All menus are properly displayed.

h3. Actual Results
The menus are from an older version of the site administration.
This is what you see:
 !Screen Shot 2018-03-27 at 11.50.06.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3.Workaround
Enable 3rd party cookies in the browser settings.
fields.summary: Old site administration menus are displayed when 3rd party cookies are disabled

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If for example, a site-admin wants to change the case of the users username from uppercase to lowercase, or in fact, any different case of the same characters they are not allowed and get the error - {{*the username belongs to xxx*}}

 
Steps to Reproduce
 # Make sure you are site-admin
 # Go to the user management console [https://INSTANCE.atlassian.net/admin/users|https://instance.atlassian.net/admin/users]
 # Select user
 # Choose Edit
 # Change case of username using same characters
 



h3. Expected Results
As usernames are not case sensitive it should be able to change the case
{{Error - *the username belongs to xxx*}}
 !username_error.jpg|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround (If there is no workaround directly say so)

Site-admin could delete the user and then re-create in the opposite case
fields.summary: Unable to change the case of username from upper to lower and vice versa

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Atlassian Account password doesn't respect the strong password policy.

h3. Environment
* Identity Manager
* Non-saml configured but password policy configured to Strong

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Sign up to Identity Manager
# Configure password policy to Strong
# Go to https://id.atlassian.com
# Change the password to a good password. (may need to test several time). Sometimes it rejects it but most of the time it accepts it. 

h3. Expected Results
Reject the password

h3. Actual Results
Accept the password
fields.summary: Strong password policy accepts good password

fields.description:
In order to help prevent bad changes from crippling the organization when changes are made in G suite that might cause many users to lose access over a short period of time, would it be possible to add configurable options to limit the number of users that can be changed over a given period of time?

The goal is to limit the damage that is caused by any issues with the information being sent or interpreted by the G suite Connector in the even that the information is not in line with what is seen in G Suite.
fields.summary: add rate limiting or Sync limiting options for Gsuite

fields.description:
When G Suite Syncs users, It can sometimes add new users or disable existing ones.
Because this can seemingly happen without warning to JIRA/Confluence Admins, it would be highly desirable to have the ability to see logs or some sort of records of the changes made by G suite syncing.

Please add these logs either to the G Suite management page, or to the Audit logs for Confluence and JIRA.
fields.summary: Add Logging for GSuite Syncs

fields.description:
Currently, it's not possible to disable or edit the invitation email when migrating a customer to Atlassian account.
It would be great if we have the option to edit the text for the customer to understand what is happening or disable the email.
fields.summary: Ability to customize the invitation email when migrating customers to Atlassian account

fields.description:
h3. Summary
This issue happen when Customer Portal and JIRA instance is set to public. At first, user created an account in Customer Portal. Then, they try to create an account with the same email when browsing the JIRA instance. This will create an Atlassian Account. Due to this, the user will have two account with same email but different username. 

h3. Environment
Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Ensure your email address is not currently associated to an Atlassian ID
# Browse to a Service Desk Portal that is open to public sign up
# Sign up for a customer account with your email address
# Log out of your new portal user account
# Browse to the non-portal homepage of the same Jira instance that has public sign up enabled
# Sign up for an Atlassian ID using the email address used to create a customer user earlier via the login/signup screen for the instance

h3. Expected Results
During user creation it should check if the account already existed in "Portal only customer" list. 

h3. Actual Results
Duplicate user account created. 
 
h3. Notes
(Optional - If Necessary)

h3.Workaround
# Browse to Jira Administration → User Management → Jira Service Desk → Portal Only Customers 
# Search for the duplicated user
# Press the Migrate to Atlassian account button
# The portal only user will now be removed, their issues will be reassigned to their new Atlassian ID Jira account.
fields.summary: User allowed to create an account with the same email in the same instance even though user already exist in "Portal on Customers" list

fields.description:
h3. Summary
A user changes the email address to a new email address.

When trying to login using the new email address the user gets the error:
"Did you use the wrong account?
Your email address new_email@address doesn't have access to instance.atlassian.net..."

h3. Environment
Jira Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Change email address.
# Log in to the instance.

h3. Expected Results
The user is able to access the instance.

h3. Actual Results

The user is not able to log in.
 
h3. Notes

h3.Workaround
Delete the user from User Management and recreate this user with the same details via the link https://instance.atlassian.net/admin/users/add.
fields.summary: After changing the email address, user is not able to log in

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Performing a reset/wipe of a cloud instance does not clear the groups in the user management.

h3. Environment

Jira and Confluence Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce

1st Method 

# Create a group
# Unsubscribe from Jira
# Wait until the data gets wiped
# Subscribe for Jira again
# Unsubscribe from Confluence
# Wait until the data gets wiped
# Check groups previously created

{quote}
The reset of your Cloud instance will remove ALL data and return all settings to their default values.
{quote}

h3. Expected Results

All the data would be wiped, however, groups are currently the only data kept.

h3. Actual Results

Groups are not cleared.

*Notes*

The current method is the following:

- https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloudkb/how-to-reset-atlassian-cloud-instance-to-the-original-default-settings-including-removal-of-all-data-691012037.html
fields.summary: Current method of reset cloud data doesn't clear the groups

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When you integrate Jira with G Suite and you deactivate users in Jira, these users sometimes are reactivated during a G Suite sync.

According to the G Suite integration [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/security-with-g-suite-938859740.html]
{quote} * Once you've connected your Atlassian Cloud site with G Suite, you'll select the user groups you want to sync from G Suite.
 * Every 4 hours, we'll run a sync from G Suite to Atlassian Cloud. The users in these groups will gain access to your Atlassian Cloud site.
 * You'll update your users' details, such as their name and email address, in G Suite. When we run our sync every 4 hours, we'll update your users in Atlassian Cloud to reflect any updates you've made.{quote}
The documentation says that users synced will gain access to Jira so it seems to be expected that inactive users would gain access and be reactivated. With this in mind, it seems like every time G Suite syncs inactive users would gain access and be reactivated.

The issue is that users are not being reactivated every time G Suite syncs. They seem to be randomly reactivated or reactivated when we click on Sync now.
h3. Customer Impact
h3. Environment
 * Instance integrated with G Suite

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Integrate an instance with G Suite
 # Deactivate a synced user in Jira
 # Click on Sync Now - the inactive user will be reactivated
 # Deactivate the same user in Jira again
 # Wait for the regular sync that runs in a 4-hour period

h3. Expected Results

Inactive users that are synced should be reactivated
h3. Actual Results

Inactive users that are synced are not always reactivated.

*Application logs:*
h3. Notes
h3. Workaround

Always make sure that you're syncing only the users you want to have access to Jira, it's possible to do that by selecting a specific group to be synced.
fields.summary: Inactive users sometimes are reactivated during a G Suite sync

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, when having SAML activated and accessing your cloud instance after inserting your email you're redirected to your configured IdP. 
On the IdP page, you have to insert the same email once more before being able to log in.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add the already inserted email into the form of the IdP.
fields.summary: Add the user email to the IdP form while redirecting the user to their IdP

fields.description:
h3. Summary  

 When a site-admin user navigates to the *people* page in the Atlassian Home for their instance, the search facility there does not return all active users in that instance

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # As a user with site-administration rights, go to [https://INSTANCE.atlassian.net/home/people|https://instance.atlassian.net/home/people]
 # See that not all the users are listed in the *Browse all* section
 # Click into search text box and search for a user that you know is in the instance but is not appearing in the *Browse all*

h3. Expected Results

The search should return the user since we know they are in the instance.
h3. Actual Results

The search function will not return the specified user but it will return "Hmm... we can’t find anyone with that name" instead.
 !active_user.jpg|thumbnail! 
 !no_result.jpg|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Workaround
Having site-admin rights you can see all the users in the administration section of your instance.
fields.summary: Not all the active users in the instance are listed in the 'people' section of the new Atlassian Home even if I am the site administrator

fields.description:
It would be interesting users could set email aliases to their Atlassian accounts. This could also be used in integrations with Google.

Currently, as per [G Suite FAQs \- |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/g-suite-faqs-873871245.html#GSuiteFAQs-ICantLogIn], email aliases are not supported. In those cases, users need to click *Having trouble logging in?* and open a link received via email.

However, in case users are actually interested in using aliases, this process is not ideal.

Desired behavior:
 * Users should have the ability to configure an alias in their Atlassian account.
fields.summary: User Alias Support

fields.description:
{panel:title=Status Update|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ff7f7f|titleBGColor=#ff7f7f|bgColor=#e5e5e5}

This issue is now resolved, and steps to configure custom project email addresses have been updated in the [Configuring Jira Cloud to send emails on behalf of your domain|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/configuring-jira-cloud-to-send-emails-on-behalf-of-your-domain-979428371.html] documentation page.

In order to be able to use a custom email, you will need to prove ownership of the domain as well as configure DNS records. 

You can validate ownership of a domain in two ways:
# The site in question is integrated with GSuite where this the domain in question is managed
# You've set up an Atlassian Organization with a valid domain claim on your domain - please follow instructions in [the documentation linked above|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/configuring-jira-cloud-to-send-emails-on-behalf-of-your-domain-979428371.html] to set this up

{panel}

h4. Summary

After following the steps in our documentation: 
- [Configuring Jira Cloud to send emails on behalf of your domain|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/configuring-jira-cloud-to-send-emails-on-behalf-of-your-domain-979428371.html]
- [Verify a domain for your organization|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/verify-a-domain-for-your-organization-873871234.html]

Customers use "[Verify Email Domain Configuration|https://domain-check.atlassian.com/]" and receive the error: 
{quote}
Domain claim failed for this domain
{quote}
Configuration settings have been correctly applied yet the error message persists. 

h4. Workaround

Please open a support request in [support.atlassian.com|https://support.atlassian.com]. We will implement the workaround on your instance.
fields.summary: Sending emails using a custom 'Project Email Address' with your domain is not possible

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When logging in with Google to a Cloud site using a Google account not in sync with the site, an Atlassian Account associated with that email gets created regardless of the user not being able to log in. 
h3. Environment

Atlassian Cloud
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # User tries to log in via Log in with Google to an Atlassian Cloud site
 # User gets a message that there is no such account in the site therefore they cannot access
 # However, Atlassian Account gets created regardless. 

h3. Expected Results

Atlassian Account does not get created as the user never logged in.
h3. Notes

This particular bug can be problematic when users try to change the email on their account as there may be another Atlassian Account associated with the destination email.

In addition, the same behavior is encountered when a user tries to reset the password on id.atlassian.com for an Account that does not exist using Google. The account gets created automatically regardless of the user just wanting to reset the password.
h3. Workaround

No workaround
fields.summary: When logging in to a Cloud site via Google, an Atlassian Account gets created regardless of the user not existing in the Cloud site

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The invite form in Internet Explorer doesn't recognize email address of a user.

h3. Environment
IE 11 Version 11.248.16299.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In Internet Explorer access the User Management and click 'Invite Users'

h3. Expected Results
* The invite form should recognize the email address and it's enclosed with border.

h3. Actual Results

Press <Space> after pasting the email address or typing the email address. This would "force" the email address to have that "border".

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If we create a user in User Management or update group membership, it is not applied to Jira/Confluence immediately, showing that the Jira/Confluence and User Management sync is not working properly.

The sync happened after a few hours (around 3 hours from the last test), while we expect it to take place immediately.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

It is quite normal that a user could have created an Atlassian Account via any service and forgot about it. At the moment, if the user is existing in Atlassian Account, they will only be notified that they were invited on JIRA/Confluence cloud. If they are not aware that they have an existing Atlassian Account, they will most likely contact the cloud administrator for a password reset. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Add the option in the invitation email to specify that they have an existing Atlassian Account and if they have forgotten the password, use the password reset link to reset their password.

h3. Why this is important
 
This could eliminate additional work from the cloud administrators to educate their users about Atlassian Account and resetting the password. 


h3. Workaround 

Add a customized invite email message when inviting users from JIRA/Confluence cloud. 

{quote}
Hi,

You have been invited to https://cloud_instance.atlassian.net. If you have an existing account in Atlassian and forgot your password, please generate a password reset email via https://id.atlassian.com/login/resetpassword. Access the password reset email to set a new password and you can use this new password together with your email address to login to https://cloud_instance.atlassian.net

Regards,
Ramon
{quote}
fields.summary: Add a password reset link option on invitation emails for users with existing Atlassian Account

 !Page.Unavailable.png|thumbnail!

User Management page unavailable

fields.description:
This can mean that if a user logs out of an Atlassian product to then try and log in with a different email on the same domain, the login will fail as Atlassian receives a different email from the IdP.

Many SAML providers support 'single sign out' which would solve this issue if integrated.

h3. Summary
If a user has two different instances, both setup with different emails, when they logged in and then switched to another instance, they will be prompted to switch an account. Clicking on *try on a different account link* wouldn't log the user out

h3. Expected Results
User gets logged out and able to switch to a different accout.

h3. Actual Results
Stuck in a constant loop telling me to switch account

h3.Workaround
Instead of clicking the *try on a different account link*, user can go to https://id.atlassian.com and logout. Or user can logout first before going to another instance
fields.summary: Logging out of Atlassian account does not log out when clicking on try on a different account link

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Having a G Suite integration for the same domain being used in a SAML integration can cause inconsistencies over the managed users data.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a user in G Suite with the email user@test.com and last name userGSuite
# Integrate G Suite in the instance for the domain test.com(this should generate a user in user management for the G Suite user)
# In your IdP create a user with the same email(user@test.com) and last name userIdP
# Create an organization do the SAML setup with your IdP

Now when the user logs in the instance with SSO his user full name will be updated to userIdP and when a sync from G Suite runs it will be updated back to userGSuite

E.G using André Kasper(Gsuite) and André Kasper(Azure):
 !G Suit.png|thumbnail! 

After login out and in:
 !IdP.png|thumbnail! 

Again, this will be set back to André Kasper(Gsuite) on the next google sync and to André Kasper(Azure) on every login.
 
h3. Notes

Also, when having an organization using the domain and then verifying it in google and integrating with GSuit the SAML domain will be flagged as *SUPERSEDED* and the SAML integration will stop working until you verify the domain again.

h3.Workaround
fields.summary: Having SAML and G Suite configured on the same instance may cause inconsistencies over users data

When inviting a user who don't have Attlasian Account, the message to create an Atlassian Account shows [object Object]

h3. Actual Results
The following message is shown:

{code}

 !image001.png|thumbnail!

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

There's a bit of a feature disparity between domains controlled through the domain verification and g suite controlled domains;

One advantage seen by verifying your domain (through Organization) is that you can see a complete list of verified email addresses and users registered on your domain across whole Atlassian Account.

This way you get a clear indication of all currently active Atlassian users from within your domain, whereas when you use the G Suite integration you will only see the accounts currently being synced through your groups, any manually created users with email addresses on your domain will not show up.

h3. Suggested Solution

As such, the G Suite integration in itself could also have good use of the User Management page from the organization management section, for the domain claimed using the G suite integration.

h3. Why this is important
 
Verifying a domain that has been claimed in G Suite is not allowed in Organization, and performing it will override the G Suite domain claim. This way, we are not able to check the Managed Accounts under our domain anymore.
fields.summary: Provide "Managed Accounts" Feature for G Suite Integration

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If a user is a member of more than 30 groups, only the first 30 groups will show when viewing the user's account in the User Management page. No pagination options show up to view additional groups past the first 30.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add user to to 31 or more groups
 # View the page to see the list of group that the user part of.

h3. Expected Results
 * Show a list of groups with pagination options at the bottom to view more groups past the initial 30

h3. Actual Results
 * List of groups that the user member of will only shown in a single page with a maximum of 30 groups. No pagination options at the bottom

h3. Notes

Issue appears to be intermittent. Some user accounts will display the pagination options on page 1 to allow you to view the rest of the groups the user is a member of.
h3. Workaround

Modify the URL to access the next page of groups. Page 2 and onwards will have pagination options on the bottom which allow you to view the rest of the groups:

https://<Instance Name>.atlassian.net/admin/users/view?start-index=30&username=<Username>
fields.summary: Incorrect list of groups for a user

fields.description:
h3.Summary

Currently the application access page doesn't show users who are in pending invitation status. These users will consume the license count but they will not show on the page (xxx.atlassian.net/admin/accessconfig). This can lead to billing contact being billed more than they should.

h3.Steps to Replicate
Invite a user to the instance. Ensure that the invited user has application access to JIRA.

h3.Expected Results
Invited user should show on application access page.

h3.Current Results
Invited user will not show on the application access page. 

h3.Workaround
Delete the invited user if they are not keen in accepting the invitation or request the user to accept the invitation.
fields.summary: JIRA application access page not showing licensed users in pending invitation status
